text:
> for Linux nothing
To be fair, for Linux you need `ssh` and `sshd`, but those come by default in every distro I can think of.

encryption key

text: You realize that 256 bits is 32 bytes, or 64 characters if you're encoding it in hex

elements.text: You realize that 256 bits is 32 bytes, or 64 characters if you're encoding it in hex

text: You'll have no problem fitting that into an envvar in any system.

text: I tryied with 4096 bit.

elements.text: I tryied with 4096 bit.

text: Don't take this as a given because I'm talking out of my ass at this point, but I don't think you'll find problems with 4096 bits.

elements.text: Don't take this as a given because I'm talking out of my ass at this point, but I don't think you'll find problems with 4096 bits.

text: I do not use such a long key in production - only for testing.

text: I don't know which encryption algorithm you're using, but for RSA and so on, 256-bit security is way too low.

text:
I am so glad that Antionio found a solution for me.
After restarting the server, I can now log in with an admin page and enter my secret code.
Now the source code has to be secured,
But I think if I use a compiled version that should be. Never compiled up to now.

elements.text:
I am so glad that Antionio found a solution for me.
After restarting the server, I can now log in with an admin page and enter my secret code.
Now the source code has to be secured,
But I think if I use a compiled version that should be. Never compiled up to now.

text: Look, I think it's great that you invest time in security, but sometimes I see you focusing on details that provide little added value.

elements.text: Look, I think it's great that you invest time in security, but sometimes I see you focusing on details that provide little added value.

text: I won't discuss the merits of compiling for "securing" any constants, but I believe security researchers would laugh at that.

elements.text: I won't discuss the merits of compiling for "securing" any constants, but I believe security researchers would laugh at that.

text: <https://securelist.com/how-we-developed-our-simple-harbour-decompiler/95517/>

attachments.title: How we developed our simple Harbour decompiler
attachments.text: There were no readily available tools to analyze how the program written in Harbour works. So, we wrote our own.

text:
I thought to reinforce the key.
The same time I enter a part of the key online I copy a file with the second part of the key.
In case someone steals the server and finds out how it works, he has to come back again and steal the part which is copied and read the env-variable the same time.
